Jill McKeon February 20, 2019 jcmckeon@bu.edu Jill McKeon Re: February 14, 2019 Public Records Request Ms. McKeon: The BPD (Boston Police Department) has received your request for public records. This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the City. See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115. It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records with respect to responses to public records requests. 950 CMR 32.04(5). Specifically, you stated: To whom it may concern, Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, M.G.L. c.66, §10, I hereby request the following records: · Any and all documents and/or data that refer to the number of Sexual Assault Evidence Collection (SAEC) kits, also known as rape kits, that have been booked into police evidence for the past 3 years. This includes kits that were under the BPD’s jurisdiction and were then sent to public and private crime laboratories. · Any and all documents and/or data that refer to the number of untested SAEC kits under BPD’s jurisdiction, broken down by year. · Any and all policies, procedures, reports and/or audits that refer to SAEC kit collection and processing. This includes but is not limited to policies and/or procedures that refer to kits that are collected but do not move forward with the testing process, as well as policies and procedures that refer to guidelines that BPD employees are required to follow in regards to the handling and processing of SAEC kits. Thank you for your commitment to maintaining transparency in our government. If you have any questions about the format or nature of the request, please contact me by email or by phone at . Please find all responsive documents to your request attached in this email. You may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. G. L. c. 66, § 10A (c); G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(ix); 950 CMR 32.08; 950 CMR 32.08(1)(h) (in petitioning the Supervisor, the requester shall provide a copy of such petition to the records access officer associated with such petition). You may also appeal to the Superior Court. 950 CMR 32.06(3)(c). Thank you, Sgt Det. John Boyle

Dan Atkinson Boston Herald February 21, 2019 Dan Atkinson Datkinson1@gmail.com Re: February 21, 2019 Public Records Request Dear Mr. Atkinson: The Boston Police Department has received your request for public records. A response to a public records request must be provided within ten (10) business days from the business day a written request was received. G. L. c. 66, § 10 (a); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(b). It is possible the City may need additional time to provide any responsive records. The City will provide a “detailed statement” to any requester should additional time be necessary to comply with a request. The public records law permits a response time of up to twenty-five (25) business days from the business day a written request is received, so long as a detailed explanation is provided. G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(vi); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(i). This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the City. See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115. It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records with respect to responses to public records requests. 950 CMR 32.04(5). Specifically, you stated: Under the Massachusetts Public Records Act § 66-10 et seq., I am requesting an opportunity to inspect or obtain copies of the following: The Vehicle Of Interest lists that BPD's License Plate Reader system uses (Amber Alert, stolen vehicle, etc.); The number of hits on each list for the past month of License Plate Reader data; The most recent Usage Audit of the License Plate Reader system, as outlined in SO 16-031, section 11; The agreement between BPD and the manager of the database where License Plate Reader data is stored. If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $100. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of a story being pursued by a media outlet, and this is request is for news gathering purposes. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes. The Massachusetts Public Records Act requires a response to this request within 10 days. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer than this amount of time, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records. If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law. Thank you for considering my request. A municipal records custodian is permitted to assess fees for the provision of public records. G. L. c. 66, § 10 (d); 950 CMR 32.07. A municipality may assess an hourly rate of up to $25.00 per hour to search for records responsive to public records requests, but may not charge for the first two hours of work. G. L. c. 66, § 10 (d) (iii); 950 CMR 32.07(2)(m). Black and white paper copies of records shall be provided at a cost of $.05 per page. It is presumed that a requester prefers electronic copies of records when available. There is no per page cost for electronic records. If necessary voluminous electronic records will be made available on a storage device. The cost of the storage device will be no more than the actual cost. Government records custodians are permitted to redact or withhold portions of public records, so long as a specific exemption to the law is cited. See G. L. c. 4, § 7 (26). Portions of records responsive to your request may contain information that is exempt from disclosure. You may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records in the O

On October 30, 2018, we received the enclosed letter from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Public Records Division, advising of its decision on our public records appeal pursuant to G.L. c. 66, § 10A. The focus of the appeal was the City of Boston Police Department's July 24, 2018 response to our request for all records related to the June 6, 2017 motor vehicle accident involving Sean Kennedy and Lee Martz at the intersection of Dartmouth Street and Warren Avenue in Boston, Massachusetts. In the attached letter, the Public Records Division found that the Boston Police Department's July 24, 2018 response was deficient in that it failed to describe the particular information redacted from the incident report under Exemptions (c) and (f), and how those exemptions specifically applied to withhold the information from disclosure. As such, the Boston Police Department did not meet is burden of demonstrating, with specificity, how the responsive information in the subject incident report is exempt from disclosure. See G.L. c. 66, § 10(b)(iv); Globe Newspaper Co. v. Police Comm'r, 419 Mass. 852,857 (1995); Reinstein v. Police Comm'r of Boston, 378 Mass. 281, 289-90 Pursuant to the letter, the Boston Police Department was ordered to provide an updated response to our public records request consistent with the Public Records Law within ten (10) business days. Joesph Borsellino Dailey & Borsellino, P.C. On August 21, 2016, my clients were passengers who were injured on a private bus for hire which was involved in an car accident on a public way in the City of Boston. All of my clients are low income females. On May 30, 2017, our office made a Freedom of Information Act Request, pursuant to M.G.L.C. 66, Section 10 upon the Boston Police Department, records access officer for all accident reports related to the August 21, 2016 accident. your office produced what appears to be a complete record of all reports. your initial production contained some redaction of information which I was informed made because the department had not yet decided whether any criminal charges would follow. On my follow up to the inquiries to the department, I was informed that no criminal charges have been or are expected to be filed. at this time, I must proceed with my clients' standard civil motor vehicle claims. the injured passengers were all lawful passengers on the bus which was operated by one bus driver and one bus driver's assistant. the accident occurred 2 and 1/4 years ago and time is of the essence in proceeding under Massachusetts limitations laws. in order to pursue their civil claim, the passengers must be able to identify the names and addresses of the bus driver and the driver's assistant. on one report, the bus driver's name is listed to be "Joe Alvarez" and his assistant's name is redacted. The address of both are also redacted. as you may know, in every civil claim, at minimum, a Massachusetts resident must be able to identify name and current address of all potentially negligent parties. Naturally, it is an important public interest that the actual involved parties are properly identified to ensure that persons who are not participants are not inadvertently identified or involved. in this case, there are likely many persons who would respond to the name "Jose Alvarez" without more. Standard civil practice authorizes the registrars of motor vehicles to routinely disclose the current address of all potential tortfeasors who maintain driver's licenses to inquiring licensed attorneys. however, a meaningful rmv search requires the last known name, address and date of birth of the potential tortfeasor. Tiesha Epps requests that 1. the Boston police department produce without redaction all of the reports relating to the subject august 16, 2016 accident including those I have attached to this request for your convenience. 2. at the minimum, produce all pages of the reports which identify the name, address and dates of birth of the bus driver, Jose Alvarez and his driver's assistant.

Adriana Lafaille ACLU BPD-ICE; new requester is Keith H. Bensten kbensten@daypitney.com -- This letter is a request under the Public Records Law, G.L. c. 66, § 10, for documents in the possession of the City of Boston and the Boston Police Department (BPD) regarding cooperation between the BPD and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The request is made on behalf of the American Civil Liberties Union ofMassachusetts, Inc., and Greater Boston Legal Services. The City of Boston and the BPD have pledged to make Boston a safe place for immigrants. Nevertheless, in a federal district court complaint filed on February 27, 2019, the U.S. Department of Labor alleges that a Boston employer unlawfully retaliated against an injured worker by causing the worker to be arrested by ICE, and that this arrest was orchestrated by two BPD officers, one of them a member of a BPD-ICE "task force." If true, the alarming allegation that the BPD facilitated ICE's arrest of an injured worker who sought legal remedies calls into question the City of Boston's commitment to workers and immigrant communities. The requested documents will help educate the public about the relationship between the BPD and ICE and provide a snapshot of communication between the two agencies during discrete time periods. We request the following: 1. All documents relating to the creation, purpose, membership, management, responsibilities, operations, effectiveness, and/or desirability of a BPD-ICE task force, or any other grouping or designation of BPD officers who communicate with ICE more frequently than their colleagues do. 2. All documents relating to the designation and/or role of particular BPD officers as points of contact or liaisons for ICE, and/or the responsibilities of said officers. 3. All communications between Boston City Hall and the BPD regarding the BPD's cooperation and/or communication with ICE, including communications about the BPD-ICE task force. 4. Any document describing the BPD's cooperation and/or communication with ICE. 5. Any document relating to specific circumstances in which BPD or other City of Boston employees are restricted· in cooperating or sharing information with ICE. 6. All documents relating to any ICE employee's access to information created or maintained by the BPD, including through the Boston Regional Intelligence Center (ERIC), COPLINK, or any other information sharing system. 7. All documents relating to requests for information or action made by ICE to the City of Boston or the BPD (including ERIC), and vice versa, since January 1, 2019, including the responses to these requests. 8. All documents relating to Tara Construction, Inc., ICE's arrest of Jose Martin Paz Flores, and/or the U.S. Department of Labor's investigation into these matters since March 29, 2017. 9. All emails, text messages, and records of other communications between employees of ICE and (a) Sergeant Detective Gregory Gallagher; (b) any officer who is a member of a BPD-ICE task force (or other comparable grouping described in paragraph 1 of this request); and/or (c) any officer serving as a point of contact or liaison to ICE during the following time periods: May 1, 2017 to May 14, 2017, and February 15, 2019 to March 1, 2019. Even where not specifically indicated, this request includes documents that are in electronic format, such as emails, and includes documents in the possession of the BRIC or any other division of the BPD. Unless otherwise specified, the request includes documents created between the time that this request is made and the time that the search is concluded.

Caroline Haskins Muckrock Media reports state that the police departments around the country have made use of Palantir's software (https: //www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/). Therefore, I am requesting the following records related to the above program: * Any software and algorithms developed for the implementation of the program. I'm particularly interested in any algorithms that have a public policy outcome, such as providing guidance on a policy or an assessment of an individual. More generally, I would like any software that was developed by or with, given to, used by, purchased or licensed to this agency for implementation of the above referenced program. This would include original source code, any compiled binaries (also known as executables), spreadsheets, program scripts, and other digital materials used to calculate any data in the above program. It would also include the input training data for machine learning algorithms. Collectively, these responsive materials will be referred to as "the software" in the following paragraphs. * All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance on the use of "the software." This includes any notes taking during meetings that discussed the use of the software, any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) of how the software works, and any other document that has been used to help explain the use of "the software" to any party, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries. This also includes any description of input and output data fields that will aid in understanding the type of information that is submitted to the software, and that is produced by the software. * A copy of any privacy impact assessments, use policies, standard operating procedures, data retention policies, legal opinions, warranties, non-disclosure agreements, contracts, liability waivers, insurance agreements, Requests for Proposals, Responses to Requests for Proposal, Memorandums of Understanding, Letters of Interest, usage policies, or informal agreements that reference "the software" or otherwise guide it use or the relationship between this agency and the provider or developer of the software. * A copy of any funding opportunity announcements, grant applications and grantor status/progress reports, reports to legislative bodies, annual reports that mention the use of the Software, as well as audit records, including but not limited to security audits of the software, misuse reports, and reports to oversight bodies. * A copy of any validation studies conducted with respect to the program or with respect to any software or algorithms used in connection with the program, and a copy of any records pertaining to inquiries for the need of validation studies, or discussion of potential or actual validation studies. By “validation study,” I mean any study designed to assess how accurate the program is in predicting what it is supposed to predict, or to assess whether the program may err in the direction of either under- or overestimating likelihoods or predicted outcomes, or may produce any results that are biased or unexpected in any way. * For the aspects of the software that require an input, for example, to compute a value, we request a copy of the five most recent sets of data that were used for input, as well as the five most recent outputs of the software, in whatever their native format is. If these inputs or outputs include exempt information, we ask that you exempt only that information which is specifically exempted from law, and provide the other material. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial p

Logan Koepke Upturn seeks records regarding the Department’s use of mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs). This includes any software, hardware, process, or service that is capable of any of the following: ? extracting any data from a mobile device, ? recovering deleted files from a mobile device, or ? bypassing mobile device passwords, locks, or other security features. Examples of MDFTs include, but are not limited to, products or services offered by vendors such as Cellebrite, Grayshift, Oxygen Forensics, BlackBag Technologies, Magnet Forensics, MSAB, AccessData, Paraben, Katana Forensics, BK Forensics, and Guidance Software/OpenText. 4 Upturn specifically requests the following records under the Massachusetts Public Records Law: 1. Purchase Records and Agreements: Any and all records reflecting an agreement for purchase, acquisition, or license of MDFTs, or permission to use, test, or evaluate MDFTs since 2015. 2. Records of Use: Any and all records describing the Department’s use of MDFTs since 2015. a. In particular, we seek records reflecting the department’s aggregate use of MDFTs. For example, monthly reports that reflect total number of MDFT cases for each month, broken down by type of crime, and number and type of phones, and number and type of other devices. i. Please specify any instances where the department used Cellebrite Advanced Services, or otherwise transferred possession of a device or its contents to a vendor for off-site processing, including Regional Computer Forensics Laboratories. 4 Our request applies to any and all records where vendor names or products are misspelled, e.g., “Greykey” instead of “Graykey,” “Greyshift” instead of “Grayshift,” and “Celle Brite,” “CellBrite”, or “Cell Brite” instead of “Cellebrite.” ii. Please include any instances of forensic examination of a device (e.g. using JTAG or chip-off processes) that may not involve a vendor’s product. 3. Policies Governing Use: Any and all records regarding policies and guidelines governing the use of MDFTs, including but not limited to: training materials regarding their operation, restrictions on when they may be used, limitations on retention and use of collected data, security measures taken to protect stored and in-transit data, guidance on when a warrant or other legal process must be obtained, and guidance on when the existence and use of MDFTs may be revealed to the public, criminal defendants, or judges.

Caroline Haskins Media reports state that the police departments around the country have made use of Palantir's software (https: //www.bloomberg.com/features/2018-palantir-peter-thiel/). Additionally, a public records request filed to the Palo Alto Police Department indicates that Palantir "will provide the technology platform to the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center for use in facilitating data sharing" between different California law enforcement agenices. Therefore, I am requesting the following records related to Palantir: * Any software and algorithms developed for the implementation of Palantir software in intelligence activities. I'm particularly interested in any algorithms that have a public policy outcome, such as providing guidance on a policy or an assessment of an individual. More generally, I would like any software that was developed by or with, given to, used by, purchased or licensed to this agency for implementation of the above referenced program. This would include original source code, any compiled binaries (also known as executables), spreadsheets, program scripts, and other digital materials used to calculate any data in the above program. It would also include the input training data for machine learning algorithms. Collectively, these responsive materials will be referred to as "the software" in the following paragraphs. * All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance on the use of "the software." This includes any notes taken during meetings that discussed the use of the software, any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) of how the software works, and any other document that has been used to help explain the use of "the software" to any party, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries. This also includes any description of input and output data fields that will aid in understanding the type of information that is submitted to the software, and that is produced by the software. * A copy of any privacy impact assessments, use policies, standard operating procedures, data retention policies, legal opinions, warranties, non-disclosure agreements, contracts, liability waivers, insurance agreements, Requests for Proposals, Responses to Requests for Proposal, Memorandums of Understanding, Letters of Interest, usage policies, or informal agreements that reference "the software" or otherwise guide it use or the relationship between this agency and the provider or developer of the software. * A copy of any funding opportunity announcements, grant applications and grantor status/progress reports, reports to legislative bodies, annual reports that mention the use of the Software, as well as audit records, including but not limited to security audits of the software, misuse reports, and reports to oversight bodies. * A copy of any validation studies conducted with respect to Palantir software in intelligence activities or with respect to any software or algorithms used in connection with Palantir software in intelligence activities, and a copy of any records pertaining to inquiries for the need of validation studies, or discussion of potential or actual validation studies. By “validation study,” I mean any study designed to assess how accurate Palantir is in predicting what it is supposed to predict, or to assess whether Palantir may err in the direction of either under- or overestimating likelihoods or predicted outcomes, or may produce any results that are biased or unexpected in any way. * For the aspects of the software that require an input, for example, to compute a value, we request a copy of the five most recent sets of data that were used for input, as well as

KEith Grayson n, My Mother’s maternal Uncle was Detective Frances, (Frank , Franny) Murphy , he was employed from around 1944 to around 1967, Franny retired and was head of security for a large radio/ TV studio until his death in 1968. My Grandmother lived with her Mother and Franny in Boston, she told me all the police knew her (Mary) and her Mother as they walked the streets and they all liked Franny. My Mother told me when Franny started with the BPD as a young man and living with my Grandmother and their Mother he would sometimes not be seen for days and use the back door to come in to avoid having his mother see his face which was bruised from scuffling. My Mother had a scrapbook my Grandmother kept with numerous clippings about Franny and his partner, I think he was Frankl Callahan? I might be wrong with his name. One of the clippings was a story about a ride along with Franny, (Frank) and his partner, it detailed how Franny was a large affable Irishman Who could instantly become someone you did not want to mess with and despite his size was fast athletic & powerful, it detailed a specific story of seeing 2 men matching a description of wanted men and Franny sprung from the car and nabbed one fellow and handed him to his partner saying if he moves “deck him” and Franny nabbed the 2nd suspect and after speaking for a few minutes Franny realized the suspects were not the wanted men and Franny became the affable Irishman once more. Another story told of a time Franny was off duty and a bunch of people were running out of a restaurant yelling , it’s a robbery! they have guns, something to that effect and Franny just charged in as everyone else was running out Franny ran in and engaged the robbers who it turned out had a fake gun, the story went on to say the suspects were so beat up the medics thought they had been shot, Lol ! Another story described Franny jumping off a fire escape or something high and landing on top of a suspect who was fleeing and Franny broke his leg, My Grandmother said Franny was very tough and was quickly promoted very early in his career into a Special Services squad a group known as Slattery’s raiders, a unit of tough men chosen by Slattery who was a really tough guy and I think Chief at one time? My Mother showed me so many clippings from numerous papers over decades, 1940’s to 1960’s, so many it seemed hard to believe, almost like Franny was best buddies with the news reporters and they wrote of his exploits often and in complimentary ways. Franny had a boat in the harbor you could live aboard or take around the world. Reading and hearing about his life always fascinated me as a kid and as an adult after getting online have tried to find stories of his career and some online sites allege to have many stories whoever they have 200,000 Frank murphy’s and in the mix are some of Franny however so far I have not found many, far less than I know existed , I hope you could assist me in detailing Franny’s lfe as he certainly was a character! My Dad said Franny was the type of detective they made shows and movies about. Anything you can do to assist me preserve this interesting piece of BPD history would be appreciated

John Plitsch Medical University of South Carolina (Department of Public Safety RE: Boston PD/ Request for Information (2017 Data)/ Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act According to the United States federal law known as the Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act (“The Clery Act”), codified at §20 USC 1092(f), colleges and universities are required to disclose statistics for certain crimes that occurred: (1) on campus, (2) on public property within and immediately adjacent to college-owned buildings and property, and (3) in or on non- campus buildings or property the University owns or controls and that are used in direct support of, or in relation to, the University’s educational mission. The University is required to disclose statistics that are reported to our University as well as crimes reported to local and state law enforcement agencies. On behalf of the Medical University of South Carolina Department of Public Safety/ Campus Police Department, I am requesting the required crime statistics, including those reports which were unfounded, for offenses specifically occurring between the below listed dates at the respective location(s), which is considered to be an “off-campus or non- campus” buildings or property controlled by the Medical University of South Carolina. As a note, a crime is considered unfounded for Clery Act purposes only if sworn or commissioned law enforcement personnel make a formal determination that the report is false or baseless. Therefore, I would appreciate you checking your records and responding as to whether any Clery crimes were reported in 2017 to your agency, per our request below. Eleanor Umphres To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, M.G.L. c.66, § 10, I hereby request the following records: • Any and all internal affairs records Detective Ken Ellis, who worked in District 13 in the early 1970s. • Any and all records pertaining to any investigation by Detective Ken Ellis into John J. Jozapaitis, for the years 1971-1982. • Any and all records pertaining to any investigation by Detective Ken Ellis into the death , for the year 1973. Please note: “[M]aterials in an internal affairs investigation are different in kind from the ordinary evaluations, performance assessments and disciplinary determinations encompassed in the public records exemption for ‘personnel [file] or information,’” and those materials in an internal affairs investigation are part of the public record. Worcester Telegram and Gazette Corp. v. Chief of Police of Worcester, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1 at 2 (2003). Additionally, per 803 CMR 2.22 (2): “Restrictions on access to, and dissemination of, an individual’s CORI shall terminate upon the individual’s death. Upon request, and with a valid death certificate or reasonable proof of death as determined by the DCJIS, an entity may access a deceased person’s entire CORI.” Therefore, please find attached to this request to the obituary for and the death certificate for . In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Yolanda Gonzalez Eberstein Witherite LLP Pursuant to the terms of the Public Information Act (formerly the Texas Open Records Act), we respectfully request the following documents, including all attachments thereto, concerning the above referenced motor vehicle accident: 1. A complete 'CERTIFIED of the Texas Peace Officer's Accident Report only. Also, Offense Incident Report, License & Weight Report of Inspection, and any subsequent supplemental reports that have been filed by or in behalf of the investigation officer(s). 2, A copy of the 'call sheet' indicating the time the accident was reported to the police, the time the call was dispatched, what police element(s)/ squad(s) were dispatched to the location, their arrival time(s), and the time they cleared from the assignment. 3. CD/disk of the complete 911 recordings/ calls. 4. A copy of the 'field notes' recorded by the investigation officer(s), including all mathematical calculations used in the reconstruction of the accident to determine any time, distance, or speed issue for any of the involved parties. 5. A set of photographs taken by your agency or provided to your agency, either at the scene of the collision or during any post-collision investigation. If any videotape(s) were taken of the accident site of subsequent investigative process, please provide one (1) copy of the tape(s). 6. Copies of all witness statements. 7. A copy of all measurements taken at the accident site and copies of any detailed or scale diagram(s) in possession of your agency depicting the accident scene. The scene measurements are normally noted in the form of a 'data block'. 8. If a Total Station (electronic survey instrument) was utilized to collect data at the scene of the collision, the following is requested: a. A computer disk copy of paper/ hard copy of any electronic data recorder file/ data that records the X, Y and/ or Z coordinates o each evidence point recorded. b. A computer disk copy of the original downloaded diagram file and the completed CAD diagram. Please note that any file formation will be accepted , but please specify either the CAD program and/ or the format utilized (i.e., . skd, .skt, .czd, .dwg, .dxf, .fix, etc.). 9. Copies of any frictional (drag factor) tests performed by your agency or provided by any outside party in regards to this motor vehicle accident. 10. A computer disk copy or paper/ hard copy of any electronic data retrieval downloads, i.e. Sensing Diagnostic Module data, utilizing a Crash Data Retrieval (CDR Tool) System or Electronic Control Module (ECM) data. 11. A computer disk copy of all recording devices, including but not limited dash cams, body cams, all recordings of the scene, all recordings in the police office, and all recordings regardless of devices or location. 12. Copies of any departmental memoranda/ messages sent or received by the investigating officer(s) concerning this accident. 13. A copy of any and all findings by any other parties; this to include any documentation, field notes and calculations that have been provided to the investigating officer and/ or your agency in regards to this motor vehicle accident. 14. A list of all physical evidence that has been removed and held in evidence or disposed of by your agency that was part of, in or about the respective vehicles involved in this collision.

Jessica Simes Boston University My name is Jessica Simes, and I am a professor of sociology at BU. I had contacted you in 2015, but I wanted to write again to see if I could make contact. My research considers the neighborhood rates of incarceration in Massachusetts, and I have worked with the MA DOC Research Division for the last seven years studying their admission and release records. I have also worked with Bruce Western and Anthony Braga on a reentry study. At the recommendation of Cliff Goodband, whom I have been working with at the State Police, I am writing to you to see if it would be possible to obtain data similar to those l collected from their NIBRS data. I am working on a dataset that examines prison admissions from 2009--2014 in Massachusetts. I was hoping to obtain geocoded data (at the census tract level) for 2008 for violent and drug crimes and arrests for the city of Boston. This data would mirror the NIBRS data provided to me by Cliff, and would provide a fuller picture of the distribution of crime in my data for the whole state, which currently doesn't contain any data on Boston for this year at such a disaggregated level. The State Police provided two datasets: violent incidences and drug incidences in 2008, and in the drug data, there was a field that indicated if there was an arrest made. I created a violent crime rate measure from their data using the UCR’s violent crime definition: murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. I then aggregated these incidences to census tracts. I then made a measure of drug arrest rates at the census tract level. My goal is to create the same measure, but for Boston census tracts, so that I can perform a statewide analysis of crime and incarceration at the tract level. Since the data from NIBRS are from 2008, I am just requesting data from that year, and if possible, just the UCR violent crimes aggregated to tracts. Please let me know if you would like further information about the research, and what steps could possibly lead to obtaining data of this sort. I sincerely appreciate your time and consideration with this request. Feel free to call me at

Keith O'Brien I'm a journalist, a former reporter for the Boston Globe, and a bestselling author whose work has appeared in the New York Times Magazine and on National Public Radio. My most recent book came out last fall. Fly Girls, published by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, tells the forgotten story of a group of female pilots fighting for the right to fly and race airplanes in the 1920s and '30s, and ultimately beating the men at their own game in one of the most celebrated air races of them all in 1936. It is a New York Times bestseller and was named one of the Times' 100 Notable Books of 2018. You can learn more at www.flygirlsbook.com. I'm doing some research into a shooting that happened in Boston in September 1979. The victim's name was Darryl Williams. Darryl was a black player on the Jamaica Plain High School football team. And during a game in Charlestown that September, three white teenagers shot him—while he was on the field—paralyzing him from the neck down. They pleaded guilty to gun charges (they said they were shooting at pigeons; not the football players) and were sentenced in 1980. Their names were Stephen McGonagle, Joseph Nardone, and Patrick Doe. Under the Freedom of Information Act, I wanted to request to view any and all documents related to the Boston Police Department's investigation into the Williams shooting, including but not limited to case files, evidence reports, transcripts of interviews or any recordings of interviews with the suspects or the original 911 dispatch call. Can you get back to me and let me know how we can proceed? Or what else you might need from me to get started? Since this case has been adjudicated, and is more than 40 years old, I would imagine the files would be public at this time. I can be reached via this email and at . Thanks so much, guys. Such devices include Amazon’s Alexa, Google Home, smart light bulbs, and other objects and appliances that connect to the internet. The company’s website can be found here: https://www.tokagroup.com/ I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Public Records Hristina Natcheva My name is Hristina Natcheva and I am writing on behalf of myself, my husband Nathan Lauren, and our neighbors Loic Vincent and Emilie Braun. We are the owners of the condo association at 469 E 4th St, South Boston, MA 02127. The association consists of two condo units, ours (#2) and Loic/Emilie's (#1). The condo building is new consturction and was completed in mid 2017. It replaced a prior single-family home with a yard at that address (Erect Permit dated 11/10/2016, permit No. ERT500382). In early August 2019, we came home after work one day and found a work crew in front of our home installing a 5G cell tower on a preexisting utility pole which is approximately 5 feet from our condo building wall. The pole had been there (owned by Crown Castle), but we had not really noticed it, as it was below the line of sight from our living room window. The "upgrade" work done to the pole resulted in significant increase in its height and the installation of a 5G cell tower directly in front of and way too close (5-10ft) to our living space. We were not notified about any of these planned changes and when we spoke with various city officials from Mayor's office, zoning, public works, etc, we were told that they will look into this and figure out what is going on. The latest communication we received from the city was from Anthony DiBona on 9/12/19, stating that the utility pole "upgrade" was approved 3 years ago - which was before our house was even built. This means that whatever work was proposed to be done to the pole and subsequently approved did not take into consideration the proximity and intrusiveness of this structure on our property and lives. We have major health and noise pollution concerns about the location and proximity of this high frequency RF radiation emitter. I recently found out I am pregnant, and given the fact that children and pregnant women are much more susceptible to the harmful effects of high energy RF radiation, I feel unsafe in my own home. We would like to request the following documentation: 1. Any and all zoning/public works records related to this particular utility pole (on the corner of E 4th St and National St, in South Boston, Crown Castle Site ID: SB010). 2. Any applications / proposals to install or upgrade a wireless facility in front of our home at 469 E 4th Street (cross street is Dorchester St). We are interested in who filed these proposals/applications, sought the relief, and who approved them on the city's end. 3. Any wireless emissions/RF safety surveys or engineering surveys that were submitted to the city in support of the safety of the installation/upgrade of this wireless facility/cell tower. Attached are some photos of the pole in question. Thank you very much for your help with this matter. Please let us know if you have any questions.

Mike Hayes I am requesting records relating to the City of Boston Procurement Department use of mobile device forensic technologies (MDFTs), as well as the City of Boston Procurement Department’s policies and procedures governing such use. I am seeking records regarding the City of Boston Procurement Department’s use of mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs). This includes any software, hardware, process, or service that is capable of any of the following: extracting any data from a mobile device, recovering deleted files from a mobile device, or bypassing mobile device passwords, locks, or other security features. Examples of MDFTs include, but are not limited to, products or services offered by vendors such as Cellebrite, Grayshift, Oxygen Forensics, BlackBag Technologies, Magnet Forensics, MSAB, AccessData, Paraben, Katana Forensics, BK Forensics, and Guidance Software/OpenText.4 I am specifically requests the following records: Purchase Records and Agreements: Any and all records reflecting an agreement for purchase, acquisition, or license of MDFTs, or permission to use, test, or evaluate MDFTs since 2014. Records of Use: Any and all records describing the City of Boston Procurement Department’s use of MDFTs since 2014. In particular, I am seeking records reflecting the City of Boston Procurement Department’s aggregate use of MDFTs. For example, monthly reports that reflect total number of MDFT cases for each month, broken down by type of crime, number and type of phones, and number and type of other devices. Please specify any instances where the City of Boston Procurement Department used Cellebrite Advanced Services, or otherwise transferred possession of a device or its contents to a vendor for off- site processing, including Regional Computer Forensics Laboratories. Please include any instances of forensic examination of a device (e.g. using JTAG or chip-off processes) that may not involve a vendor’s product. Policies Governing Use: Any and all records regarding policies and guidelines governing the use of MDFTs, including but not limited to: training materials regarding their operation, restrictions on when they may be used, limitations on retention and use of collected data, security measures taken to protect stored and in-transit data, guidance on when a warrant or other legal process must be obtained, and guidance on when the existence and use of MDFTs may be revealed to the public, criminal defendants, or judges. This request applies to any and all records where vendor names or products are misspelled, e.g., “Greykey” instead of “Graykey,” “Greyshift” instead of “Grayshift,” and “Celle Brite,” “CellBrite”, or “Cell Brite” instead of “Cellebrite.”

For example, monthly reports that reflect total number of MDFT cases for each month, broken down by type of crime, number and type of phones, and number and type of other devices. Please specify any instances where the City of Boston Procurement Department used Cellebrite Advanced Services, or otherwise transferred possession of a device or its contents to a vendor for off- site processing, including Regional Computer Forensics Laboratories. Please include any instances of forensic examination of a device (e.g. using JTAG or chip-off processes) that may not involve a vendor’s product. Policies Governing Use: Any and all records regarding policies and guidelines governing the use of MDFTs, including but not limited to: training materials regarding their operation, restrictions on when they may be used, limitations on retention and use of collected data, security measures taken to protect stored and in-transit data, guidance on when a warrant or other legal process must be obtained, and guidance on when the existence and use of MDFTs may be revealed to the public, criminal defendants, or judges. This request applies to any and all records where vendor names or products are misspelled, e.g., “Greykey” instead of “Graykey,” “Greyshift” instead of “Grayshift,” and “Celle Brite,” “CellBrite”, or “Cell Brite” instead of “Cellebrite.”
